comment.body:
_üõ†Ô∏è Refactor suggestion_

**Avoid crash when _train_step returns None and remove redundant gradient clipping.**

- If _train_step returns None (no loss), .item() will raise. Guard it.
- _clip_gradients is already called inside _update; calling it here is redundant.


Apply this diff:

```diff
-        for i, batch in enumerate(train_loop):
-            step_loss += self._train_step(batch).item()
-            if (i + 1) % self.accumulation_steps == 0:
-                self._clip_gradients()
+        for i, batch in enumerate(train_loop):
+            loss = self._train_step(batch)
+            if loss is not None:
+                step_loss += loss.item()
+            if (i + 1) % self.accumulation_steps == 0:
                 self._update()
                 self._accumulate_metrics(
                     metrics, step_loss, epoch_loss, step=(epoch * len(train_loop)) + i
                 )
                 step_loss = 0
```

<!-- suggestion_start -->

<details>
<summary>üìù Committable suggestion</summary>

> ‚ÄºÔ∏è **IMPORTANT**
> Carefully review the code before committing. Ensure that it accurately replaces the highlighted code, contains no missing lines, and has no issues with indentation. Thoroughly test & benchmark the code to ensure it meets the requirements.

```suggestion
        for i, batch in enumerate(train_loop):
            loss = self._train_step(batch)
            if loss is not None:
                step_loss += loss.item()
            if (i + 1) % self.accumulation_steps == 0:
                self._update()
                self._accumulate_metrics(
                    metrics, step_loss, epoch_loss, step=(epoch * len(train_loop)) + i
                )
                step_loss = 0
        self._log_batch(metrics)
```

</details>

<!-- suggestion_end -->

<details>
<summary>ü§ñ Prompt for AI Agents</summary>

```
In corebehrt/modules/trainer/causal/trainer.py around lines 115 to 123, guard
against _train_step returning None before calling .item() and remove the
redundant call to self._clip_gradients(); specifically, call loss =
self._train_step(batch) and if loss is None skip adding to step_loss and skip
any operations that expect a numeric loss for this micro-step (continue to next
iteration), otherwise add loss.item() to step_loss; also delete the
self._clip_gradients() call here since gradient clipping is already performed
inside self._update(), and ensure step_loss is reset to 0 only when an
accumulation block completes and after metrics are accumulated.
```

</details>

**Critical: Exposure computation relies on a likely-missing "EXPOSURE" vocabulary entry**

_binary_exposure = self._compute_exposure_from_censored_data(data)_ assumes a vocabulary key "EXPOSURE" exists, which is not configured anywhere (ExposureConfig has no concept code setting). This will either mislabel or raise ValueError and deviates from the prior, well-defined exposure label computation from the cohort exposures file + follow-up window.

Recommend reverting exposure label computation to use the cohort exposures + follow-up (consistent with _compute_binary_labels and the rest of the pipeline).

+
+def _plot_censor_dates(ax: plt.axes, censor_dates: pd.Series, y_map: Dict[int, int]):
+    """Plots censor dates as vertical dashed lines."""
+    if censor_dates is None or censor_dates.empty:
+        return
+
+    censor_df = censor_dates.reset_index()
+    censor_df.columns = [PID_COL, "censor_abspos"]
+    censor_df[PID_COL] = censor_df[PID_COL].astype(int)
+
+    # Filter for subjects in our plot
+    subjects_in_plot = list(y_map.keys())
+    censor_df = censor_df[censor_df[PID_COL].isin(subjects_in_plot)]
+
+    if censor_df.empty:
+        return
+
+    censor_df["censor_dt"] = get_datetime_from_hours_since_epoch(
+        censor_df["censor_abspos"]
+    )
+
+    for _, row in censor_df.iterrows():
+        pid = int(row[PID_COL])
+        y = y_map[pid]
+        ax.vlines(
+            x=row["censor_dt"],
+            ymin=y - 0.4,
+            ymax=y + 0.4,
+            color="dimgray",
+            linestyle="--",
+            lw=1.5,
+            label="Censor Date",
+            zorder=4,  # Just below events
+        )
+
+
+def plot_followups_timeline(
+    exposures: pd.DataFrame,
+    outcomes: Optional[Dict[str, pd.DataFrame]],
+    follow_ups: pd.DataFrame,
+    index_date_matching: pd.DataFrame,
+    censor_dates: pd.Series,
+    subject_ids: Optional[List[int]] = None,
+    n_random_subjects: int = 8,
+    title: str = "Follow-up Timeline (Exposures & Outcomes)",
+    outcome_colors: Optional[Dict[str, str]] = None,
+    save_dir: Optional[str] = None,
+    seed: int = 42,
+):
+    """
+    Matplotlib timeline showing follow-up windows, exposures, outcomes, censor dates, and deaths.
+    When selecting subjects randomly, their matched pairs (if any) are also included.
+
+    - exposures: DataFrame with PID_COL and ABSPOS_COL (hours since epoch)
+    - outcomes: Dict[name -> DataFrame with PID_COL and ABSPOS_COL]
+    - follow_ups: DataFrame with PID_COL, START_COL, END_COL, DEATH_COL (hours since epoch)
+    - index_date_matching: DataFrame with control_subject_id, exposed_subject_id
+    - censor_dates: Series with PID_COL as index and censor_date (hours since epoch) as values
+    """
+    if follow_ups is None or follow_ups.empty:
+        print("No follow-ups provided. Nothing to plot.")
+        return
+
+    # --- REFACTORED: Subject Selection Logic ---
+    if not subject_ids:
+        subject_groups = _get_subject_groups(
+            follow_ups, index_date_matching, n_random_subjects, seed
+        )
+        subject_ids = [pid for group in subject_groups for pid in group]
+    else:
+        all_pids = set(follow_ups[PID_COL].astype(int).unique())
+        subject_ids = [int(pid) for pid in subject_ids if int(pid) in all_pids]
+        subject_groups = [[pid] for pid in subject_ids]
+
+    if not subject_ids:
+        print("No valid subject_ids found to plot.")
+        return
+
+    # --- REFACTORED: Centralized Data Preparation ---
+    fu_plot = follow_ups[follow_ups[PID_COL].isin(subject_ids)].copy()
+    fu_plot["start_dt"] = get_datetime_from_hours_since_epoch(fu_plot[START_COL])
+    fu_plot["end_dt"] = get_datetime_from_hours_since_epoch(fu_plot[END_COL])
+
+    # --- REFACTORED: Prepare death data for unified event plotting ---
+    death_events = None
+    if DEATH_COL in fu_plot.columns and fu_plot[DEATH_COL].notna().any():
+        deaths_df = fu_plot[[PID_COL, DEATH_COL]].dropna().copy()
+        deaths_df = deaths_df.rename(columns={DEATH_COL: ABSPOS_COL})
+        death_events = deaths_df
+
+    # --- PLOTTING SETUP ---
+    height = max(3, 0.45 * len(subject_ids))
+    fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(12, height))
+
+    y_pos, y_map = 0, {}
+    for group in subject_groups:
+        for pid in group:
+            y_map[pid] = y_pos
+            y_pos += 1
+
+    # --- NEW: Add background shading for matched groups ---
+    group_colors = ["#F0F0F0", "white"]  # Alternating light gray and white
+    for i, group in enumerate(subject_groups):
+        # Only add shading for actual groups (more than 1 person)
+        if len(group) > 1:
+            y_coords = [y_map[pid] for pid in group]
+            # The span should cover the vertical space of the group
+            ax.axhspan(
+                min(y_coords) - 0.5,
+                max(y_coords) + 0.5,
+                color=group_colors[i % 2],
+                zorder=0,  # zorder=0 sends it to the very back
+                alpha=0.7,
+            )
+
+    date_range = fu_plot["end_dt"].max() - fu_plot["start_dt"].min()
+    text_offset = date_range * 0.01
+
+    # --- PLOT TIMELINE BARS ---
+    for _, row in fu_plot.iterrows():
+        y = y_map[int(row[PID_COL])]
+        ax.hlines(
+            y=y, xmin=row["start_dt"], xmax=row["end_dt"], color="lightgray", lw=2
+        )
+
+        pid = int(row[PID_COL])
+        patient_type = ""
+        if not index_date_matching.empty:
+            if pid in index_date_matching["exposed_subject_id"].values:
+                patient_type = " (E)"
+            elif pid in index_date_matching["control_subject_id"].values:
+                patient_type = " (C)"
+

**YAML numeric literals: underscores likely parsed as strings**

In YAML, numeric digit separators like underscores are not standard and are typically parsed as strings by common parsers (e.g., PyYAML). If the code expects an int for n_hours_censoring, this can cause subtle type bugs downstream.

review.body:
**Actionable comments posted: 13**
üî≠ Outside diff range comments (4)
corebehrt/modules/trainer/causal/trainer.py (3)
`130-175`: **Gradient accumulation is currently broken (zero_grad called every micro-batch) and losses aren‚Äôt normalized.** Calling zero_grad inside _train_step wipes accumulated grads each micro-step; accumulation never happens. Also, losses should be divided by accumulation_steps to keep effective LR stable. Apply this diff to fix both issues: ```diff def _train_step(self, batch: dict): self.global_step += 1 - self.optimizer.zero_grad() self.batch_to_device(batch) with torch.autocast(device_type=self.device.type, dtype=torch.bfloat16): outputs = self.model(batch) if self.use_pcgrad: # Collect individual task losses for PCGrad task_losses = [] @@ if not task_losses: return outputs.loss if hasattr(outputs, "loss") else None - # Scale each loss individually for PCGrad - scaled_losses = [self.scaler.scale(loss) for loss in task_losses] + # Normalize by accumulation steps before scaling + accum = getattr(self, "accumulation_steps", 1) + normalized_losses = [loss / accum for loss in task_losses] + # Scale each loss individually for PCGrad + scaled_losses = [self.scaler.scale(loss) for loss in normalized_losses] @@ # Return the total loss for logging (unscaled) return outputs.loss if hasattr(outputs, "loss") else sum(task_losses) else: loss = outputs.loss if loss is not None: - self.scaler.scale(loss).backward() + accum = getattr(self, "accumulation_steps", 1) + self.scaler.scale(loss / accum).backward() return loss ``` --- `512-526`: **Handle missing validation dataset to avoid None dereference.** When no validation set is provided, evaluate() returns Nones; current code calls val_metrics.get(...), which will crash. Apply this diff to guard and early-return: ```diff def validate_and_log(self, epoch: int, epoch_loss: float, train_loop) -> None: - ( - val_loss, - val_metrics, - val_exposure_loss, - val_outcome_loss, - val_prediction_data, - ) = self.evaluate(mode="val") - _, test_metrics, test_exposure_loss, test_outcome_loss, test_prediction_data = ( - self.evaluate(mode="test") - ) + val_result = self.evaluate(mode="val") + if not val_result or val_result[0] is None: + self.log("No validation dataset provided; skipping validation/test logging.") + return + ( + val_loss, + val_metrics, + val_exposure_loss, + val_outcome_loss, + val_prediction_data, + ) = val_result + + test_result = self.evaluate(mode="test") + if test_result and test_result[0] is not None: + _, test_metrics, test_exposure_loss, test_outcome_loss, test_prediction_data = test_result + else: + test_metrics, test_exposure_loss, test_outcome_loss, test_prediction_data = None, None, None, None ``` --- `533-541`: **‚ÄúSaving results‚Äù is logged but save_results=False prevents artifacts from being written.** The intent is to save artifacts when a new best model is found. Pass save_results=True. Apply this diff: ```diff - # If it's the best, save all the detailed artifacts + # If it's the best, save all the detailed artifacts if self.accumulate_logits: self.process_causal_classification_results( - val_prediction_data, mode="val", save_results=False + val_prediction_data, mode="val", save_results=True ) if test_prediction_data: self.process_causal_classification_results( - test_prediction_data, mode="test", save_results=False + test_prediction_data, mode="test", save_results=True ) ```
corebehrt/modules/preparation/causal/prepare_data.py (1)
`453-463`: **Convert and guard outcome assignment before calling `assign_outcomes`** `assign_outcomes` expects a `dict[str, pd.Series]`, but we‚Äôre passing a `DataFrame`. Convert the DataFrame to a dict-of-series and skip assignment if it‚Äôs empty: ‚Ä¢ File: corebehrt/modules/preparation/causal/prepare_data.py Lines ~458‚Äì463 ```diff self.logger.info("Assigning exposures and outcomes") data.assign_attributes(EXPOSURE, binary_exposure) - data.assign_outcomes(binary_outcomes) + # Convert DataFrame to dict[str, Series], then assign if nonempty + outcomes_dict = ( + binary_outcomes.to_dict(orient="series") + if binary_outcomes is not None + else {} + ) + if outcomes_dict: + data.assign_outcomes(outcomes_dict) + else: + self.logger.warning( + "No outcomes passed post-filtering; skipping outcome assignment." + ) ``` This ensures correct input type and avoids surprising failures when there are no outcomes to assign.
‚ôªÔ∏è Duplicate comments (6)
corebehrt/modules/trainer/causal/trainer.py (1)
`186-203`: **Move gradient plotting before optimizer step (as per docstring) and zero grads post-step.** Gradients may be cleared after step/update; plot them immediately before stepping. Also, zero gradients once per update, not per micro-batch. Apply this diff: ```diff def _update(self): """Updates the model (optimizer and scheduler) with PCGrad support""" # PCGrad optimizer exposes param_groups, so scaler can work with it directly self._clip_gradients() + # Plot gradients after backward and clipping, before stepping + if ( + self.global_step % self.plot_gradients_frequency == 0 + ) and self.plot_gradients: + plot_gradient_distributions( + self.model, + self.optimizer, + self.scaler, + self.log, + self.run_folder, + self.global_step, + ) self.scaler.step(self.optimizer) self.scaler.update() - if ( - self.global_step % self.plot_gradients_frequency == 0 - ) and self.plot_gradients: - plot_gradient_distributions( - self.model, - self.optimizer, - self.scaler, - self.log, - self.run_folder, - self.global_step, - ) + # Clear grads for next accumulation window + if hasattr(self.optimizer, "zero_grad"): + self.optimizer.zero_grad() ```
corebehrt/functional/preparation/causal/utils.py (1)
`51-58`: **Preserve PID dtype; avoid forcing int for GROUP_COL** For non-integer PIDs (or mixed dtypes between follow_ups and index_date_matching), `astype(int)` will fail or coerce incorrectly. Align GROUP_COL‚Äôs dtype with PID_COL (use pandas nullable Int64 for numeric IDs). Apply: ```diff - follow_ups[GROUP_COL] = follow_ups[PID_COL].map(control_to_group_map) - # 3. Fill the `NaN` values. The NaNs correspond to exposed patients. - # We fill the NaN with the patient's own ID, making the exposed_pid the group ID. - follow_ups[GROUP_COL] = follow_ups[GROUP_COL].fillna(follow_ups[PID_COL]) - - # Ensure the group column is an integer type. - follow_ups[GROUP_COL] = follow_ups[GROUP_COL].astype(int) + mapped = follow_ups[PID_COL].map(control_to_group_map) + # Exposed or unmatched get their own ID + follow_ups.loc[:, GROUP_COL] = mapped.fillna(follow_ups[PID_COL]) + # Align dtype to PID_COL where possible + pid_dtype = follow_ups[PID_COL].dtype + try: + if pd.api.types.is_integer_dtype(pid_dtype) or pd.api.types.is_unsigned_integer_dtype(pid_dtype): + # Use nullable Int64 for safety if NAs arise in future + follow_ups.loc[:, GROUP_COL] = follow_ups[GROUP_COL].astype("Int64") + elif pd.api.types.is_string_dtype(pid_dtype) or pid_dtype == object: + follow_ups.loc[:, GROUP_COL] = follow_ups[GROUP_COL].astype("string") + # Otherwise, leave as-is to avoid coercion issues on exotic dtypes + except Exception: + # Defensive: do not fail group assignment due to dtype issues + pass ``` Optionally, coerce both sides to strings during mapping to avoid dtype mismatches, then cast back to the desired dtype.
corebehrt/functional/visualize/follow_ups.py (1)
`347-356`: **Handle None/empty index_date_matching to avoid AttributeError** Same issue flagged previously remains: `.copy()` and `.columns` access on None/empty will raise. Use a safe normalization. ```diff - matching_df = index_date_matching.copy() - if "control_subject_id" in matching_df.columns: - matching_df["control_subject_id"] = matching_df["control_subject_id"].astype( - int - ) - if "exposed_subject_id" in matching_df.columns: - matching_df["exposed_subject_id"] = matching_df["exposed_subject_id"].astype( - int - ) + # Normalize matching dataframe; allow None/empty gracefully + if index_date_matching is None or index_date_matching.empty: + matching_df = pd.DataFrame(columns=["control_subject_id", "exposed_subject_id"]) + else: + matching_df = index_date_matching.copy() + for col in ("control_subject_id", "exposed_subject_id"): + if col in matching_df.columns: + matching_df[col] = matching_df[col].astype(int) ```
corebehrt/modules/preparation/causal/dataset.py (1)
`114-115`: **torch.tensor(patient.pid, dtype=torch.long) will fail for string PIDs; pre-encode IDs** PID is a string across the codebase. Converting it directly to a LongTensor will raise a TypeError at runtime. This also conflicts with generic ‚Äúmove the whole batch to device‚Äù patterns that assume tensor values. Apply this safe, localized fix that pre-encodes PIDs to stable integers in the dataset and emits the encoded id: ```diff class ExposureOutcomesDataset: @@ - def __init__(self, patients: List[CausalPatientData]): - self.patients = patients - self.collate_fn = dynamic_padding + def __init__(self, patients: List[CausalPatientData]): + self.patients = patients + self.collate_fn = dynamic_padding + # Map original string PIDs to stable integer ids for tensorization and device moves + self._pid2idx: dict[str, int] = {} + for p in self.patients: + if p.pid not in self._pid2idx: + self._pid2idx[p.pid] = len(self._pid2idx) @@ - PID_COL: torch.tensor(patient.pid, dtype=torch.long), + PID_COL: torch.tensor(self._pid2idx[patient.pid], dtype=torch.long), ``` If you need to convert model outputs back to original PIDs, keep a reverse map: ```python self._idx2pid: dict[int, str] = {v: k for k, v in self._pid2idx.items()} def decode_pid(self, idx: int) -> str: return self._idx2pid[int(idx)] ```
corebehrt/modules/preparation/causal/prepare_data.py (2)
`124-126`: **ABSPOS precomputation before censoring ‚Äî LGTM** Ensuring ABSPOS_COL exists before censoring/truncation avoids the KeyError previously flagged. --- `557-563`: **Harden get_end_date: support strings/ts-like, safe default, and warning when defaulting** Current code assumes dict (pd.Timestamp(**data_end)) and unguarded access to cohort_cfg.time_windows; both are fragile and can raise. Apply: ```diff - def get_end_date(cohort_cfg): - time_windows = cohort_cfg.time_windows - if data_end := time_windows.get("data_end"): - return pd.Timestamp(**data_end) - else: - return pd.Timestamp.now() + def get_end_date(cohort_cfg): + time_windows = getattr(cohort_cfg, "time_windows", {}) or {} + data_end = time_windows.get("data_end") + if data_end is None: + logger.warning("time_windows.data_end not found; defaulting to current time (non-reproducible).") + return pd.Timestamp.now() + try: + # Handles strings, pandas/numpy datetime-like, and timestamps + return pd.Timestamp(data_end) + except Exception: + if isinstance(data_end, dict): + return pd.Timestamp(**data_end) + raise ValueError(f"Unsupported data_end format: {data_end!r}") ```
üßπ Nitpick comments (22)
corebehrt/modules/trainer/causal/trainer.py (1)
`54-56`: **Guard against invalid plot_gradients_frequency (avoid modulo-by-zero).** A user-provided 0 (or non-int) would break the modulo condition. Clamp to at least 1 and coerce to int. Apply this diff: ```diff - self.plot_gradients = self.args.get("plot_gradients", False) - self.plot_gradients_frequency = self.args.get("plot_gradients_frequency", 100) + self.plot_gradients = self.args.get("plot_gradients", False) + self.plot_gradients_frequency = max( + 1, int(self.args.get("plot_gradients_frequency", 100)) + ) ```
corebehrt/modules/io/encodings.py (1)
`7-9`: **Union type syntax requires Python 3.10+** `int | None` needs Python 3.10+. If your supported runtime includes 3.9, switch to Optional[int]. Apply if 3.9 support is required: ```diff +from typing import Optional - -class ShardLoader: - def __init__(self, shard_dir: str, num_shards: int | None = None): +class ShardLoader: + def __init__(self, shard_dir: str, num_shards: Optional[int] = None): self.shard_dir = shard_dir self.num_shards = num_shards ```
corebehrt/configs/causal/select_cohort_full/extract_uncensored.yaml (2)
`17-25`: **YAML numeric literals with leading zeros: avoid YAML 1.1 octal ambiguity** Use consistent, unambiguous numbers (no leading zeros) or quote them as strings. You currently have `month: 01` under data_end but `month: 1` under data_start. Apply: ```diff - data_end: - year: 2100 - month: 01 - day: 01 + data_end: + year: 2100 + month: 1 + day: 1 ``` --- `31-34`: **val_ratio/test_ratio are unused with cv_folds > 1** With `cv_folds: 2`, `val_ratio` (noted in comment) and likely `test_ratio` won‚Äôt be used. Keep for documentation if you plan to switch folds at runtime; otherwise, consider removing to avoid confusion.
corebehrt/functional/preparation/causal/utils.py (1)
`41-42`: **Nit: trailing hash in comment** Minor typo: trailing '#' at the end of the comment. Apply: ```diff - # This series will have control_pids as the index and exposed_pids as values.# + # This series will have control_pids as the index and exposed_pids as values. ```
corebehrt/modules/trainer/encodings.py (3)
`118-121`: **Avoid ambiguous truth-value on tensors: use `.item()` with `mask.any()`** In PyTorch, relying on implicit bool conversion of tensors can be brittle. Make the intent explicit. ```diff - if not mask.any(): # Skip if no valid tokens in the batch + if not mask.any().item(): # Skip if no valid tokens in the batch return ``` --- `82-89`: **Speed up dataloading with workers and pinned memory** Encoding extraction is typically IO-bound; modest parallelism helps. Consider enabling a few workers and pinned memory for CUDA. ```diff - return DataLoader( - self.dataset, - batch_size=self.batch_size, - shuffle=False, - collate_fn=self.dataset.collate_fn, - ) + return DataLoader( + self.dataset, + batch_size=self.batch_size, + shuffle=False, + collate_fn=self.dataset.collate_fn, + num_workers=min(8, (os.cpu_count() or 1)), + pin_memory=(self.device.type == "cuda"), + persistent_workers=True, + ) ``` --- `91-97`: **Simplify mask construction with `torch.isin`** Vectorized isin is faster and more idiomatic than a Python loop over ignore IDs. ```diff - mask = torch.ones_like(concepts, dtype=torch.bool, device=self.device) - for token_id in self.ignore_token_ids: - mask &= concepts != token_id + if self.ignore_token_ids: + ignore = torch.tensor( + list(self.ignore_token_ids), device=concepts.device, dtype=concepts.dtype + ) + mask = ~torch.isin(concepts, ignore) + else: + mask = torch.ones_like(concepts, dtype=torch.bool, device=self.device) return mask ```
corebehrt/main_causal/helper/finetune_exp_y.py (1)
`120-122`: **Confirm output directory creation for weight plots** If `visualize_weight_distributions` doesn‚Äôt create `save_dir`, this will fail. Either create the folder here or ensure the utility creates it. ```diff - if cfg.get("visualize_weight_distributions", False): - visualize_weight_distributions(model, save_dir=join(fold_folder, "figs")) + if cfg.get("visualize_weight_distributions", False): + figs_dir = join(fold_folder, "figs") + os.makedirs(figs_dir, exist_ok=True) + visualize_weight_distributions(model, save_dir=figs_dir) ```

Align with _prepare_followup_data_for_coverage. ```diff - for col in [start_col, end_col, index_col]: - if pd.api.types.is_datetime64_any_dtype(df[col]): - df[col] = pd.to_datetime(df[col]).apply(get_hours_since_epoch) + for col in [start_col, end_col, index_col]: + if pd.api.types.is_string_dtype(df[col]) or pd.api.types.is_datetime64_any_dtype(df[col]): + df[col] = pd.to_datetime(df[col]).apply(get_hours_since_epoch) ```

The asymmetry could lead to inconsistent labeling if the code assumes comparable windows. Apply this diff for typing safety: ```diff - n_hours_start_follow_up: -1_000_000 # start follow up (considering outcomes) time after index date (negative means before) + n_hours_start_follow_up: -1000000 # start follow up (considering outcomes) time after index date (negative means before) ``` If the intent is fully uncensored for both exposure and outcomes, consider also revisiting `exposure.n_hours_start_follow_up` to match; otherwise ignore.

corebehrt/modules/preparation/causal/prepare_data.py (8)
`162-179`: **Create figure directory and guard empty outcomes before plotting** Some plotting functions handle mkdir, others may not; and plotting outcome distributions with an empty DataFrame is noisy. Apply: ```diff if follow_ups is not None: fig_dir = join(self.paths_cfg.prepared_data, "figures") + os.makedirs(fig_dir, exist_ok=True) plot_follow_up_duration_distribution(follow_ups, binary_exposure, fig_dir) plot_followup_coverage( follow_ups, binary_exposure, fig_dir, mode="relative" ) plot_followup_coverage( follow_ups, binary_exposure, fig_dir, mode="absolute" ) plot_followup_start_end_distribution( follow_ups, binary_exposure, fig_dir, mode="relative" ) plot_followup_start_end_distribution( follow_ups, binary_exposure, fig_dir, mode="absolute" ) - plot_outcome_distribution(binary_outcomes, fig_dir) + if not binary_outcomes.empty: + plot_outcome_distribution(binary_outcomes, fig_dir) + else: + self.logger.warning("binary_outcomes is empty; skipping outcome distribution plot.") plot_filtering_stats(filtering_stats, fig_dir) plot_followups_timeline( exposures=exposures, outcomes=outcomes, follow_ups=follow_ups, index_date_matching=index_date_matching, censor_dates=censor_dates, save_dir=fig_dir, n_random_subjects=30, ) ``` --- `225-333`: **Dead code: _compute_binary_labels is no longer used** This method duplicates logic now split between exposure computation and _compute_outcome_labels and is unused. Keeping it increases maintenance burden and the risk of divergence. Consider removing _compute_binary_labels altogether or reusing it directly from prepare_finetune_data to avoid duplication. --- `335-343`: **Outcome-only path: good separation, but ensure config-driven thresholds are used consistently** This method is a cleaner outcome-only path. However, see separate comment about min_instances usage and comments about "Empty since we're not using it" which is misleading here. --- `356-360`: **Align comments and threshold source for outcomes** - The comments on the exposures argument say ‚ÄúEmpty since we're not using it for outcomes,‚Äù yet it is correctly passed to support non-compliance (compliance windows) in get_combined_follow_ups. Clarify comments. - Use the OutcomeConfig threshold consistently (current code mixes sources across methods). Apply: ```diff - exposures=exposures, # Empty since we're not using it for outcomes + exposures=exposures, # Used for non-compliance windows (n_hours_compliance) @@ - exposures=exposures, # Empty since we're not using it for outcomes + exposures=exposures, # Used for non-compliance windows (n_hours_compliance) @@ - min_instances_per_class = self.min_instances_per_class + min_instances_per_class = self.outcome_cfg.min_instances_per_class ``` Also applies to: 369-373, 377-377 --- `418-423`: **Guard logging when binary_outcomes is empty** binary_outcomes.apply(pd.Series.value_counts) on an empty DataFrame is harmless but noisy. Optional: skip this log when empty. --- `424-430`: **Death outcome check is fine; consider normalizing names once** Optional: precompute lname = outcome_name.lower() once if this is hot; otherwise fine as-is. --- `431-452`: **Remove or harden _compute_exposure_from_censored_data** As noted earlier, relying on vocabulary["EXPOSURE"] is brittle without config. If you adopt the cohort-based exposure computation, this method becomes dead code and should be removed. Apply: ```diff - def _compute_exposure_from_censored_data( - self, data: CausalPatientDataset - ) -> pd.Series: - """ - Computes exposure targets based on the presence of exposure concepts - in the censored patient concept data. - - This ensures consistency between the exposure targets and the actual - concepts available in the censored sequences. - """ - exposure_code = self.vocabulary.get("EXPOSURE") - if exposure_code is None: - raise ValueError("EXPOSURE concept not found in vocabulary") - - exposure_targets = {} - for patient in data.patients: - # Check if exposure concept is present in the censored concept data - has_exposure = int(exposure_code in set(patient.concepts)) - exposure_targets[patient.pid] = has_exposure - - return pd.Series(exposure_targets, name="exposure") + # (method removed; exposure labels computed from cohort exposures + follow-up) ``` --- `565-576`: **Skip saving empty outcomes and add explicit index handling where helpful** Avoid writing empty outcomes and be explicit about index for series to_csv calls. Apply: ```diff artifacts.data.save(out_dir) artifacts.exposures.to_csv(join(out_dir, EXPOSURES_FILE), index=False) artifacts.index_dates.to_csv(join(out_dir, INDEX_DATES_FILE), index=False) artifacts.follow_ups.to_csv(join(out_dir, FOLLOW_UPS_FILE), index=False) - artifacts.binary_outcomes.to_csv(join(out_dir, BINARY_OUTCOMES_FILE)) - artifacts.binary_exposure.to_csv(join(out_dir, BINARY_EXPOSURE_FILE)) + if artifacts.binary_outcomes is not None and not artifacts.binary_outcomes.empty: + artifacts.binary_outcomes.to_csv(join(out_dir, BINARY_OUTCOMES_FILE)) + else: + logger.warning("binary_outcomes is empty; skipping save.") + artifacts.binary_exposure.to_csv(join(out_dir, BINARY_EXPOSURE_FILE)) ```

  * Many new visualizations: outcome distributions, paginated outcome figures, effect‚Äësize/contingency/adjustment plots, follow‚Äëup timelines, index‚Äëdate distributions, IPW/weight & gradient histograms.
  * Optional saving of model encodings and optional model weight visualizations.

* **Improvements**
  * Expanded plotting configuration and memory‚Äëefficient, paginated plotting for large datasets.
  * Training/evaluation workflow enhancements and optional gradient plotting.

* **Bug Fixes**
  * Inclusive follow‚Äëup boundaries and fixes preventing negative follow‚Äëup durations.

* **Tests**
  * Added/updated tests for grouping, follow‚Äëups, index‚Äëdate validation, and outcome combinations.
<!-- end of auto-generated comment: release notes by coderabbit.ai -->

review.body:
**Actionable comments posted: 13**
üî≠ Outside diff range comments (4)
corebehrt/modules/trainer/causal/trainer.py (3)
`130-175`: **Gradient accumulation is currently broken (zero_grad called every micro-batch) and losses aren‚Äôt normalized.** Calling zero_grad inside _train_step wipes accumulated grads each micro-step; accumulation never happens. Also, losses should be divided by accumulation_steps to keep effective LR stable. Apply this diff to fix both issues: ```diff def _train_step(self, batch: dict): self.global_step += 1 - self.optimizer.zero_grad() self.batch_to_device(batch) with torch.autocast(device_type=self.device.type, dtype=torch.bfloat16): outputs = self.model(batch) if self.use_pcgrad: # Collect individual task losses for PCGrad task_losses = [] @@ if not task_losses: return outputs.loss if hasattr(outputs, "loss") else None - # Scale each loss individually for PCGrad - scaled_losses = [self.scaler.scale(loss) for loss in task_losses] + # Normalize by accumulation steps before scaling + accum = getattr(self, "accumulation_steps", 1) + normalized_losses = [loss / accum for loss in task_losses] + # Scale each loss individually for PCGrad + scaled_losses = [self.scaler.scale(loss) for loss in normalized_losses] @@ # Return the total loss for logging (unscaled) return outputs.loss if hasattr(outputs, "loss") else sum(task_losses) else: loss = outputs.loss if loss is not None: - self.scaler.scale(loss).backward() + accum = getattr(self, "accumulation_steps", 1) + self.scaler.scale(loss / accum).backward() return loss ``` --- `512-526`: **Handle missing validation dataset to avoid None dereference.** When no validation set is provided, evaluate() returns Nones; current code calls val_metrics.get(...), which will crash. Apply this diff to guard and early-return: ```diff def validate_and_log(self, epoch: int, epoch_loss: float, train_loop) -> None: - ( - val_loss, - val_metrics, - val_exposure_loss, - val_outcome_loss, - val_prediction_data, - ) = self.evaluate(mode="val") - _, test_metrics, test_exposure_loss, test_outcome_loss, test_prediction_data = ( - self.evaluate(mode="test") - ) + val_result = self.evaluate(mode="val") + if not val_result or val_result[0] is None: + self.log("No validation dataset provided; skipping validation/test logging.") + return + ( + val_loss, + val_metrics, + val_exposure_loss, + val_outcome_loss, + val_prediction_data, + ) = val_result + + test_result = self.evaluate(mode="test") + if test_result and test_result[0] is not None: + _, test_metrics, test_exposure_loss, test_outcome_loss, test_prediction_data = test_result + else: + test_metrics, test_exposure_loss, test_outcome_loss, test_prediction_data = None, None, None, None ``` --- `533-541`: **‚ÄúSaving results‚Äù is logged but save_results=False prevents artifacts from being written.** The intent is to save artifacts when a new best model is found. Pass save_results=True. Apply this diff: ```diff - # If it's the best, save all the detailed artifacts + # If it's the best, save all the detailed artifacts if self.accumulate_logits: self.process_causal_classification_results( - val_prediction_data, mode="val", save_results=False + val_prediction_data, mode="val", save_results=True ) if test_prediction_data: self.process_causal_classification_results( - test_prediction_data, mode="test", save_results=False + test_prediction_data, mode="test", save_results=True ) ```
corebehrt/modules/preparation/causal/prepare_data.py (1)
`453-463`: **Convert and guard outcome assignment before calling `assign_outcomes`** `assign_outcomes` expects a `dict[str, pd.Series]`, but we‚Äôre passing a `DataFrame`. Convert the DataFrame to a dict-of-series and skip assignment if it‚Äôs empty: ‚Ä¢ File: corebehrt/modules/preparation/causal/prepare_data.py Lines ~458‚Äì463 ```diff self.logger.info("Assigning exposures and outcomes") data.assign_attributes(EXPOSURE, binary_exposure) - data.assign_outcomes(binary_outcomes) + # Convert DataFrame to dict[str, Series], then assign if nonempty + outcomes_dict = ( + binary_outcomes.to_dict(orient="series") + if binary_outcomes is not None + else {} + ) + if outcomes_dict: + data.assign_outcomes(outcomes_dict) + else: + self.logger.warning( + "No outcomes passed post-filtering; skipping outcome assignment." + ) ``` This ensures correct input type and avoids surprising failures when there are no outcomes to assign.
‚ôªÔ∏è Duplicate comments (6)
corebehrt/modules/trainer/causal/trainer.py (1)
`186-203`: **Move gradient plotting before optimizer step (as per docstring) and zero grads post-step.** Gradients may be cleared after step/update; plot them immediately before stepping. Also, zero gradients once per update, not per micro-batch. Apply this diff: ```diff def _update(self): """Updates the model (optimizer and scheduler) with PCGrad support""" # PCGrad optimizer exposes param_groups, so scaler can work with it directly self._clip_gradients() + # Plot gradients after backward and clipping, before stepping + if ( + self.global_step % self.plot_gradients_frequency == 0 + ) and self.plot_gradients: + plot_gradient_distributions( + self.model, + self.optimizer, + self.scaler, + self.log, + self.run_folder, + self.global_step, + ) self.scaler.step(self.optimizer) self.scaler.update() - if ( - self.global_step % self.plot_gradients_frequency == 0 - ) and self.plot_gradients: - plot_gradient_distributions( - self.model, - self.optimizer, - self.scaler, - self.log, - self.run_folder, - self.global_step, - ) + # Clear grads for next accumulation window + if hasattr(self.optimizer, "zero_grad"): + self.optimizer.zero_grad() ```
corebehrt/functional/preparation/causal/utils.py (1)
`51-58`: **Preserve PID dtype; avoid forcing int for GROUP_COL** For non-integer PIDs (or mixed dtypes between follow_ups and index_date_matching), `astype(int)` will fail or coerce incorrectly. Align GROUP_COL‚Äôs dtype with PID_COL (use pandas nullable Int64 for numeric IDs). Apply: ```diff - follow_ups[GROUP_COL] = follow_ups[PID_COL].map(control_to_group_map) - # 3. Fill the `NaN` values. The NaNs correspond to exposed patients. - # We fill the NaN with the patient's own ID, making the exposed_pid the group ID. - follow_ups[GROUP_COL] = follow_ups[GROUP_COL].fillna(follow_ups[PID_COL]) - - # Ensure the group column is an integer type. - follow_ups[GROUP_COL] = follow_ups[GROUP_COL].astype(int) + mapped = follow_ups[PID_COL].map(control_to_group_map) + # Exposed or unmatched get their own ID + follow_ups.loc[:, GROUP_COL] = mapped.fillna(follow_ups[PID_COL]) + # Align dtype to PID_COL where possible + pid_dtype = follow_ups[PID_COL].dtype + try: + if pd.api.types.is_integer_dtype(pid_dtype) or pd.api.types.is_unsigned_integer_dtype(pid_dtype): + # Use nullable Int64 for safety if NAs arise in future + follow_ups.loc[:, GROUP_COL] = follow_ups[GROUP_COL].astype("Int64") + elif pd.api.types.is_string_dtype(pid_dtype) or pid_dtype == object: + follow_ups.loc[:, GROUP_COL] = follow_ups[GROUP_COL].astype("string") + # Otherwise, leave as-is to avoid coercion issues on exotic dtypes + except Exception: + # Defensive: do not fail group assignment due to dtype issues + pass ``` Optionally, coerce both sides to strings during mapping to avoid dtype mismatches, then cast back to the desired dtype.
corebehrt/functional/visualize/follow_ups.py (1)
`347-356`: **Handle None/empty index_date_matching to avoid AttributeError** Same issue flagged previously remains: `.copy()` and `.columns` access on None/empty will raise. Use a safe normalization. ```diff - matching_df = index_date_matching.copy() - if "control_subject_id" in matching_df.columns: - matching_df["control_subject_id"] = matching_df["control_subject_id"].astype( - int - ) - if "exposed_subject_id" in matching_df.columns: - matching_df["exposed_subject_id"] = matching_df["exposed_subject_id"].astype( - int - ) + # Normalize matching dataframe; allow None/empty gracefully + if index_date_matching is None or index_date_matching.empty: + matching_df = pd.DataFrame(columns=["control_subject_id", "exposed_subject_id"]) + else: + matching_df = index_date_matching.copy() + for col in ("control_subject_id", "exposed_subject_id"): + if col in matching_df.columns: + matching_df[col] = matching_df[col].astype(int) ```
corebehrt/modules/preparation/causal/dataset.py (1)
`114-115`: **torch.tensor(patient.pid, dtype=torch.long) will fail for string PIDs; pre-encode IDs** PID is a string across the codebase. Converting it directly to a LongTensor will raise a TypeError at runtime. This also conflicts with generic ‚Äúmove the whole batch to device‚Äù patterns that assume tensor values. Apply this safe, localized fix that pre-encodes PIDs to stable integers in the dataset and emits the encoded id: ```diff class ExposureOutcomesDataset: @@ - def __init__(self, patients: List[CausalPatientData]): - self.patients = patients - self.collate_fn = dynamic_padding + def __init__(self, patients: List[CausalPatientData]): + self.patients = patients + self.collate_fn = dynamic_padding + # Map original string PIDs to stable integer ids for tensorization and device moves + self._pid2idx: dict[str, int] = {} + for p in self.patients: + if p.pid not in self._pid2idx: + self._pid2idx[p.pid] = len(self._pid2idx) @@ - PID_COL: torch.tensor(patient.pid, dtype=torch.long), + PID_COL: torch.tensor(self._pid2idx[patient.pid], dtype=torch.long), ``` If you need to convert model outputs back to original PIDs, keep a reverse map: ```python self._idx2pid: dict[int, str] = {v: k for k, v in self._pid2idx.items()} def decode_pid(self, idx: int) -> str: return self._idx2pid[int(idx)] ```
corebehrt/modules/preparation/causal/prepare_data.py (2)
`124-126`: **ABSPOS precomputation before censoring ‚Äî LGTM** Ensuring ABSPOS_COL exists before censoring/truncation avoids the KeyError previously flagged. --- `557-563`: **Harden get_end_date: support strings/ts-like, safe default, and warning when defaulting** Current code assumes dict (pd.Timestamp(**data_end)) and unguarded access to cohort_cfg.time_windows; both are fragile and can raise. Apply: ```diff - def get_end_date(cohort_cfg): - time_windows = cohort_cfg.time_windows - if data_end := time_windows.get("data_end"): - return pd.Timestamp(**data_end) - else: - return pd.Timestamp.now() + def get_end_date(cohort_cfg): + time_windows = getattr(cohort_cfg, "time_windows", {}) or {} + data_end = time_windows.get("data_end") + if data_end is None: + logger.warning("time_windows.data_end not found; defaulting to current time (non-reproducible).") + return pd.Timestamp.now() + try: + # Handles strings, pandas/numpy datetime-like, and timestamps + return pd.Timestamp(data_end) + except Exception: + if isinstance(data_end, dict): + return pd.Timestamp(**data_end) + raise ValueError(f"Unsupported data_end format: {data_end!r}") ```
üßπ Nitpick comments (22)
corebehrt/modules/trainer/causal/trainer.py (1)
`54-56`: **Guard against invalid plot_gradients_frequency (avoid modulo-by-zero).** A user-provided 0 (or non-int) would break the modulo condition. Clamp to at least 1 and coerce to int. Apply this diff: ```diff - self.plot_gradients = self.args.get("plot_gradients", False) - self.plot_gradients_frequency = self.args.get("plot_gradients_frequency", 100) + self.plot_gradients = self.args.get("plot_gradients", False) + self.plot_gradients_frequency = max( + 1, int(self.args.get("plot_gradients_frequency", 100)) + ) ```
corebehrt/modules/io/encodings.py (1)
`7-9`: **Union type syntax requires Python 3.10+** `int | None` needs Python 3.10+. If your supported runtime includes 3.9, switch to Optional[int]. Apply if 3.9 support is required: ```diff +from typing import Optional - -class ShardLoader: - def __init__(self, shard_dir: str, num_shards: int | None = None): +class ShardLoader: + def __init__(self, shard_dir: str, num_shards: Optional[int] = None): self.shard_dir = shard_dir self.num_shards = num_shards ```
corebehrt/configs/causal/select_cohort_full/extract_uncensored.yaml (2)
`17-25`: **YAML numeric literals with leading zeros: avoid YAML 1.1 octal ambiguity** Use consistent, unambiguous numbers (no leading zeros) or quote them as strings. You currently have `month: 01` under data_end but `month: 1` under data_start. Apply: ```diff - data_end: - year: 2100 - month: 01 - day: 01 + data_end: + year: 2100 + month: 1 + day: 1 ``` --- `31-34`: **val_ratio/test_ratio are unused with cv_folds > 1** With `cv_folds: 2`, `val_ratio` (noted in comment) and likely `test_ratio` won‚Äôt be used. Keep for documentation if you plan to switch folds at runtime; otherwise, consider removing to avoid confusion.
corebehrt/functional/preparation/causal/utils.py (1)
`41-42`: **Nit: trailing hash in comment** Minor typo: trailing '#' at the end of the comment. Apply: ```diff - # This series will have control_pids as the index and exposed_pids as values.# + # This series will have control_pids as the index and exposed_pids as values. ```
corebehrt/modules/trainer/encodings.py (3)
`118-121`: **Avoid ambiguous truth-value on tensors: use `.item()` with `mask.any()`** In PyTorch, relying on implicit bool conversion of tensors can be brittle. Make the intent explicit. ```diff - if not mask.any(): # Skip if no valid tokens in the batch + if not mask.any().item(): # Skip if no valid tokens in the batch return ``` --- `82-89`: **Speed up dataloading with workers and pinned memory** Encoding extraction is typically IO-bound; modest parallelism helps. Consider enabling a few workers and pinned memory for CUDA. ```diff - return DataLoader( - self.dataset, - batch_size=self.batch_size, - shuffle=False, - collate_fn=self.dataset.collate_fn, - ) + return DataLoader( + self.dataset, + batch_size=self.batch_size, + shuffle=False, + collate_fn=self.dataset.collate_fn, + num_workers=min(8, (os.cpu_count() or 1)), + pin_memory=(self.device.type == "cuda"), + persistent_workers=True, + ) ``` --- `91-97`: **Simplify mask construction with `torch.isin`** Vectorized isin is faster and more idiomatic than a Python loop over ignore IDs. ```diff - mask = torch.ones_like(concepts, dtype=torch.bool, device=self.device) - for token_id in self.ignore_token_ids: - mask &= concepts != token_id + if self.ignore_token_ids: + ignore = torch.tensor( + list(self.ignore_token_ids), device=concepts.device, dtype=concepts.dtype + ) + mask = ~torch.isin(concepts, ignore) + else: + mask = torch.ones_like(concepts, dtype=torch.bool, device=self.device) return mask ```
corebehrt/main_causal/helper/finetune_exp_y.py (1)
`120-122`: **Confirm output directory creation for weight plots** If `visualize_weight_distributions` doesn‚Äôt create `save_dir`, this will fail. Either create the folder here or ensure the utility creates it. ```diff - if cfg.get("visualize_weight_distributions", False): - visualize_weight_distributions(model, save_dir=join(fold_folder, "figs")) + if cfg.get("visualize_weight_distributions", False): + figs_dir = join(fold_folder, "figs") + os.makedirs(figs_dir, exist_ok=True) + visualize_weight_distributions(model, save_dir=figs_dir) ```
corebehrt/functional/visualize/follow_ups.py (1)
`53-56`: **Handle string-typed start/end columns (consistency with coverage prep)** In this function, start/end get converted only if datetime dtype. If they are strings, downstream math breaks. Align with _prepare_followup_data_for_coverage. ```diff - for col in [start_col, end_col, index_col]: - if pd.api.types.is_datetime64_any_dtype(df[col]): - df[col] = pd.to_datetime(df[col]).apply(get_hours_since_epoch) + for col in [start_col, end_col, index_col]: + if pd.api.types.is_string_dtype(df[col]) or pd.api.types.is_datetime64_any_dtype(df[col]): + df[col] = pd.to_datetime(df[col]).apply(get_hours_since_epoch) ```
.github/workflows/causal_pipeline_uncensored.yml (1)
`70-76`: **Remove trailing whitespace to satisfy linters** YAML lint flagged trailing spaces (Line 74). Clean up trailing spaces in this block to avoid CI noise. Apply this minimal diff: ```diff - name: Validate uncensored data preparation shell: bash run: | set -euo pipefail - python -m tests.pipeline.test_uncensored_prepared --processed_data_dir ./outputs/causal/finetune/prepared_data_uncensored ```
corebehrt/configs/causal/finetune/prepare/uncensored.yaml (1)
`36-41`: **Same underscore issue for outcome start follow-up; also review exposure/outcome window alignment** - Remove underscores to ensure proper integer typing. - Optional: Confirm that using -1000000 for outcome start but -1 for exposure start is intentional. The asymmetry could lead to inconsistent labeling if the code assumes comparable windows. Apply this diff for typing safety: ```diff - n_hours_start_follow_up: -1_000_000 # start follow up (considering outcomes) time after index date (negative means before) + n_hours_start_follow_up: -1000000 # start follow up (considering outcomes) time after index date (negative means before) ``` If the intent is fully uncensored for both exposure and outcomes, consider also revisiting `exposure.n_hours_start_follow_up` to match; otherwise ignore.
corebehrt/modules/preparation/causal/dataset.py (1)
`8-15`: **Type annotation style nit** Minor consistency nit: this file mixes typing.Dict/List with builtin generics (dict[str, ...]). Consider standardizing on builtin generics for Python 3.10+.
tests/pipeline/test_uncensored_prepared.py (1)
`121-122`: **Use sys.exit for clarity** Prefer sys.exit over bare exit in scripts. Apply this diff: ```diff - exit(1) + import sys + sys.exit(1) ```
corebehrt/modules/preparation/causal/prepare_data.py (8)
`162-179`: **Create figure directory and guard empty outcomes before plotting** Some plotting functions handle mkdir, others may not; and plotting outcome distributions with an empty DataFrame is noisy. Apply: ```diff if follow_ups is not None: fig_dir = join(self.paths_cfg.prepared_data, "figures") + os.makedirs(fig_dir, exist_ok=True) plot_follow_up_duration_distribution(follow_ups, binary_exposure, fig_dir) plot_followup_coverage( follow_ups, binary_exposure, fig_dir, mode="relative" ) plot_followup_coverage( follow_ups, binary_exposure, fig_dir, mode="absolute" ) plot_followup_start_end_distribution( follow_ups, binary_exposure, fig_dir, mode="relative" ) plot_followup_start_end_distribution( follow_ups, binary_exposure, fig_dir, mode="absolute" ) - plot_outcome_distribution(binary_outcomes, fig_dir) + if not binary_outcomes.empty: + plot_outcome_distribution(binary_outcomes, fig_dir) + else: + self.logger.warning("binary_outcomes is empty; skipping outcome distribution plot.") plot_filtering_stats(filtering_stats, fig_dir) plot_followups_timeline( exposures=exposures, outcomes=outcomes, follow_ups=follow_ups, index_date_matching=index_date_matching, censor_dates=censor_dates, save_dir=fig_dir, n_random_subjects=30, ) ``` --- `225-333`: **Dead code: _compute_binary_labels is no longer used** This method duplicates logic now split between exposure computation and _compute_outcome_labels and is unused. Keeping it increases maintenance burden and the risk of divergence. Consider removing _compute_binary_labels altogether or reusing it directly from prepare_finetune_data to avoid duplication. --- `335-343`: **Outcome-only path: good separation, but ensure config-driven thresholds are used consistently** This method is a cleaner outcome-only path. However, see separate comment about min_instances usage and comments about "Empty since we're not using it" which is misleading here. --- `356-360`: **Align comments and threshold source for outcomes** - The comments on the exposures argument say ‚ÄúEmpty since we're not using it for outcomes,‚Äù yet it is correctly passed to support non-compliance (compliance windows) in get_combined_follow_ups. Clarify comments. - Use the OutcomeConfig threshold consistently (current code mixes sources across methods). Apply: ```diff - exposures=exposures, # Empty since we're not using it for outcomes + exposures=exposures, # Used for non-compliance windows (n_hours_compliance) @@ - exposures=exposures, # Empty since we're not using it for outcomes + exposures=exposures, # Used for non-compliance windows (n_hours_compliance) @@ - min_instances_per_class = self.min_instances_per_class + min_instances_per_class = self.outcome_cfg.min_instances_per_class ``` Also applies to: 369-373, 377-377 --- `418-423`: **Guard logging when binary_outcomes is empty** binary_outcomes.apply(pd.Series.value_counts) on an empty DataFrame is harmless but noisy. Optional: skip this log when empty. --- `424-430`: **Death outcome check is fine; consider normalizing names once** Optional: precompute lname = outcome_name.lower() once if this is hot; otherwise fine as-is. --- `431-452`: **Remove or harden _compute_exposure_from_censored_data** As noted earlier, relying on vocabulary["EXPOSURE"] is brittle without config. If you adopt the cohort-based exposure computation, this method becomes dead code and should be removed. Apply: ```diff - def _compute_exposure_from_censored_data( - self, data: CausalPatientDataset - ) -> pd.Series: - """ - Computes exposure targets based on the presence of exposure concepts - in the censored patient concept data. - - This ensures consistency between the exposure targets and the actual - concepts available in the censored sequences. - """ - exposure_code = self.vocabulary.get("EXPOSURE") - if exposure_code is None: - raise ValueError("EXPOSURE concept not found in vocabulary") - - exposure_targets = {} - for patient in data.patients: - # Check if exposure concept is present in the censored concept data - has_exposure = int(exposure_code in set(patient.concepts)) - exposure_targets[patient.pid] = has_exposure - - return pd.Series(exposure_targets, name="exposure") + # (method removed; exposure labels computed from cohort exposures + follow-up) ``` --- `565-576`: **Skip saving empty outcomes and add explicit index handling where helpful** Avoid writing empty outcomes and be explicit about index for series to_csv calls. Apply: ```diff artifacts.data.save(out_dir) artifacts.exposures.to_csv(join(out_dir, EXPOSURES_FILE), index=False) artifacts.index_dates.to_csv(join(out_dir, INDEX_DATES_FILE), index=False) artifacts.follow_ups.to_csv(join(out_dir, FOLLOW_UPS_FILE), index=False) - artifacts.binary_outcomes.to_csv(join(out_dir, BINARY_OUTCOMES_FILE)) - artifacts.binary_exposure.to_csv(join(out_dir, BINARY_EXPOSURE_FILE)) + if artifacts.binary_outcomes is not None and not artifacts.binary_outcomes.empty: + artifacts.binary_outcomes.to_csv(join(out_dir, BINARY_OUTCOMES_FILE)) + else: + logger.warning("binary_outcomes is empty; skipping save.") + artifacts.binary_exposure.to_csv(join(out_dir, BINARY_EXPOSURE_FILE)) ```

pull_request.title: Refactor: Split large CLI command files into logical modules
pull_request.body:
## Summary

This PR refactors the large CLI command files into focused, maintainable modules. The refactoring improves code organization while maintaining 100% backward compatibility.

## Files Refactored

### üìß **`email.rs`** (867 lines ‚Üí 6 modules)
- **`analytics.rs`** - Email tracking and analytics functionality
- **`core.rs`** - Core email operations (send, setup)
- **`providers.rs`** - Provider operations (test, configure, switch)
- **`queue.rs`** - Queue operations (status, process, clear)
- **`templates.rs`** - Template management (list, validate, render)
- **`testing.rs`** - Testing/capture functionality (capture, list, show, clear, export)

### üîÑ **`queue.rs`** (795 lines ‚Üí 3 modules)
- **`queue_work.rs`** - Work processing functionality for background job execution
- **`queue_status.rs`** - Status monitoring functionality for queue inspection
- **`queue_scheduler.rs`** - Scheduled commands and daemon functionality for cron-like jobs

### üîê **`auth.rs`** (761 lines ‚Üí 3 modules)
- **`auth_setup.rs`** - Auth system setup and configuration
- **`auth_scaffold.rs`** - Scaffolding (user models, controllers, migrations)
- **`auth_generators.rs`** - Key generation functionality

### üÜï **`new.rs`** (492 lines ‚Üí 2 modules)
- **`new_app.rs`** - Main application creation functionality
- **`new_templates.rs`** - Template generation and file creation

### ‚öôÔ∏è **`interactive_setup.rs`** (410 lines ‚Üí 2 modules)
- **`interactive_wizard.rs`** - Interactive project setup wizard functionality
- **`interactive_config.rs`** - Configuration collection and generation

## Key Benefits

- ‚úÖ **Improved maintainability**: Each module has a single, focused responsibility
- ‚úÖ **Better code organization**: Related functionality is grouped together logically
- ‚úÖ **Enhanced readability**: Smaller, more manageable files are easier to navigate
- ‚úÖ **Zero breaking changes**: All existing functionality preserved with the same public API
- ‚úÖ **Consistent patterns**: Modular structure follows the same pattern across all commands
- ‚úÖ **Future development**: New features can be added to the appropriate module

## Testing

All functionality has been thoroughly tested:

- ‚úÖ **Build verification**: `cargo build` completes successfully with no errors
- ‚úÖ **CLI functionality**: All commands work exactly as before
- ‚úÖ **Help system**: All help commands display correctly
- ‚úÖ **Module integration**: Proper re-export structure maintains original public interface

### Command Testing Results
```bash
$ elifrs --help        # ‚úÖ Main help works
$ elifrs email --help  # ‚úÖ Email commands work  
$ elifrs queue --help  # ‚úÖ Queue commands work
$ elifrs auth --help   # ‚úÖ Auth commands work
```

## Technical Details

### Module Structure
Each refactored command follows this pattern:
```
crates/cli/src/commands/[command]/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ mod.rs              # Module declarations and re-exports
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ [command]_[area].rs # Focused functionality modules
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ [command]_[area].rs # Additional modules as needed
```

### Backward Compatibility
- All original imports continue to work without modification
- External code using these modules requires no changes
- All CLI commands maintain their exact same behavior and help text

## Code Quality

- **Focused modules**: Each module has a clear, single responsibility
- **Clean separation**: Related functionality is properly grouped
- **Consistent imports**: All dependencies correctly maintained across modules
- **Documentation**: Each module includes appropriate documentation
- **Error handling**: All original error handling logic preserved

ü§ñ Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)

comment.body:
@Cai1Hsu, you're absolutely right! Thank you for the clarification. 

I see now that `VirtualAddress::from_ref` with the `T: ?Sized` bound correctly handles fat pointers like slices by casting them to thin pointers (`r as *const T as *const ()`). The existing `From<&T>` implementation (lines 28-31) covers slices since `&[T]` is just `&T` where `T = [ItemType]`, and it properly delegates to `from_ref` which discards the slice metadata and uses just the data pointer.

My suggestion for a separate `From<&[T]>` implementation was unnecessary since the generic `From<&T>` already handles this case correctly.

---

<details>
<summary>‚úèÔ∏è Learnings added</summary>

```
Learnt from: Cai1Hsu
PR: caiyih/bakaos#78
File: libraries/address/src/virtual_address.rs:214-221
Timestamp: 2025-08-17T14:30:33.549Z
Learning: VirtualAddress::from_ref<T: ?Sized>(r: &T) handles fat pointer conversion by casting `r as *const T as *const ()`, which takes the data pointer part and discards metadata like slice length. The generic From<&T> implementation covers slices (&[T]) since they're just &T where T is the slice type.
```

> Note: Learnings are effective only in the context of similar code segments. To apply general coding guidelines, please configure [review instructions](https://docs.coderabbit.ai/guides/review-instructions). You can manage existing learnings in the [app](https://app.coderabbit.ai/learnings).

</details>

pull_request.title: feat(address): implement more into for VirtualAddress
pull_request.body:
This PR adds more `into VirtualAddress` conversion ability for various types, especially on &T and &impl Deref.

- Add specialization feature(necessary to impl trait for both &impl Deref and &T) to allow for more specific implementations
- Implement From trait for &T, &[T] and impl Deref references
- implementations for impl Deref types are on reference to avoid taking ownership. You can use `box.as_ref().into()` for values


<!-- This is an auto-generated comment: release notes by coderabbit.ai -->
## Summary by CodeRabbit

* **New Features**
  * More ergonomic, idiomatic conversions from references, pointers and slices to virtual-address values via standard conversion traits.

* **Refactor**
  * Replaced legacy conversion patterns with trait-based implementations and clarified pointer-derivation behavior.

* **Tests**
  * Expanded tests to cover the new conversion paths across various borrowed and boxed inputs.

* **Chores**
  * Enabled required nightly compiler features (no runtime or public API behavior changes).

pull_request.title: feat(address): implement more into for VirtualAddress
pull_request.body:
This PR adds more `into VirtualAddress` conversion ability for various types, especially on &T and &impl Deref.

- Add specialization feature(necessary to impl trait for both &impl Deref and &T) to allow for more specific implementations
- Implement From trait for &T, &[T] and impl Deref references
- implementations for impl Deref types are on reference to avoid taking ownership. You can use `box.as_ref().into()` for values


<!-- This is an auto-generated comment: release notes by coderabbit.ai -->
## Summary by CodeRabbit

* **New Features**
  * More ergonomic, idiomatic conversions from references, pointers and slices to virtual-address values via standard conversion traits.

* **Refactor**
  * Replaced legacy conversion patterns with trait-based implementations and clarified pointer-derivation behavior.

* **Tests**
  * Expanded tests to cover the new conversion paths across various borrowed and boxed inputs.

* **Chores**
  * Enabled required nightly compiler features (no runtime or public API behavior changes).
<!-- end of auto-generated comment: release notes by coderabbit.ai -->

pull_request.title: Refactor: Split large CLI command files into logical modules
pull_request.body:
## Summary

This PR refactors the large CLI command files into focused, maintainable modules. The refactoring improves code organization while maintaining 100% backward compatibility.

## Files Refactored

### üìß **`email.rs`** (867 lines ‚Üí 6 modules)
- **`analytics.rs`** - Email tracking and analytics functionality
- **`core.rs`** - Core email operations (send, setup)
- **`providers.rs`** - Provider operations (test, configure, switch)
- **`queue.rs`** - Queue operations (status, process, clear)
- **`templates.rs`** - Template management (list, validate, render)
- **`testing.rs`** - Testing/capture functionality (capture, list, show, clear, export)

### üîÑ **`queue.rs`** (795 lines ‚Üí 3 modules)
- **`queue_work.rs`** - Work processing functionality for background job execution
- **`queue_status.rs`** - Status monitoring functionality for queue inspection
- **`queue_scheduler.rs`** - Scheduled commands and daemon functionality for cron-like jobs

### üîê **`auth.rs`** (761 lines ‚Üí 3 modules)
- **`auth_setup.rs`** - Auth system setup and configuration
- **`auth_scaffold.rs`** - Scaffolding (user models, controllers, migrations)
- **`auth_generators.rs`** - Key generation functionality

### üÜï **`new.rs`** (492 lines ‚Üí 2 modules)
- **`new_app.rs`** - Main application creation functionality
- **`new_templates.rs`** - Template generation and file creation

### ‚öôÔ∏è **`interactive_setup.rs`** (410 lines ‚Üí 2 modules)
- **`interactive_wizard.rs`** - Interactive project setup wizard functionality
- **`interactive_config.rs`** - Configuration collection and generation

## Key Benefits

- ‚úÖ **Improved maintainability**: Each module has a single, focused responsibility
- ‚úÖ **Better code organization**: Related functionality is grouped together logically
- ‚úÖ **Enhanced readability**: Smaller, more manageable files are easier to navigate
- ‚úÖ **Zero breaking changes**: All existing functionality preserved with the same public API
- ‚úÖ **Consistent patterns**: Modular structure follows the same pattern across all commands
- ‚úÖ **Future development**: New features can be added to the appropriate module

## Testing

All functionality has been thoroughly tested:

- ‚úÖ **Build verification**: `cargo build` completes successfully with no errors
- ‚úÖ **CLI functionality**: All commands work exactly as before
- ‚úÖ **Help system**: All help commands display correctly
- ‚úÖ **Module integration**: Proper re-export structure maintains original public interface

### Command Testing Results
```bash
$ elifrs --help        # ‚úÖ Main help works
$ elifrs email --help  # ‚úÖ Email commands work  
$ elifrs queue --help  # ‚úÖ Queue commands work
$ elifrs auth --help   # ‚úÖ Auth commands work
```

## Technical Details

### Module Structure
Each refactored command follows this pattern:
```
crates/cli/src/commands/[command]/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ mod.rs              # Module declarations and re-exports
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ [command]_[area].rs # Focused functionality modules
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ [command]_[area].rs # Additional modules as needed
```

### Backward Compatibility
- All original imports continue to work without modification
- External code using these modules requires no changes
- All CLI commands maintain their exact same behavior and help text

## Code Quality

- **Focused modules**: Each module has a clear, single responsibility
- **Clean separation**: Related functionality is properly grouped
- **Consistent imports**: All dependencies correctly maintained across modules
- **Documentation**: Each module includes appropriate documentation
- **Error handling**: All original error handling logic preserved

issue.title: Cannot Post Status Using Gboard on Android 16 ‚Äì ‚ÄúText can‚Äôt be blank‚Äù (HTTP 422)
issue.body:
When attempting to post a status in Mastodon for Android, the app fails with the error:

> Validation failed: Text can't be blank

This occurs even when text has been entered into the composer. The server returns HTTP 422.

**Environment:**

- **App:** org.joinmastodon.android v140
- **OS:** Android 16 (BP2A.250805.005), GrapheneOS (google/tokay/tokay:16/BP2A.250805.005/2025081400:user/release-keys)
- **Keyboard:** Gboard (com.google.android.inputmethod.latin v171306542, targetSdk 35)
- **User type:** full.secondary
- **Device flags:** developer options enabled
- **Server:** Mastodon v4.x (glitch-soc fork, goingdark.social)

**Steps to Reproduce:**

1. Install Mastodon for Android v140 on Android 16 (GrapheneOS).
2. Set Gboard (v171306542) as the default keyboard.
3. Open the status composer in Mastodon.
4. Enter any text (e.g., ‚Äútest‚Äù).
5. Tap Post.

**Expected Behavior:**  
Status should be posted and visible as a new post.

**Actual Behavior:**  
A toast/error message appears:  
> Validation failed: Text can't be blank  
Server responds with HTTP 422 and JSON:  
`{"error":"Validation failed: Text can't be blank"}`

Logcat shows:  
`SpannableStringBuilder: SPAN_EXCLUSIVE_EXCLUSIVE spans cannot have a zero length`  
before the 422 error.

**Relevant Log Excerpts:**  
From Mastodon app logcat:  
`08-17 11:58:37.584 6929 6929 E SpannableStringBuilder: SPAN_EXCLUSIVE_EXCLUSIVE spans cannot have a zero length`  
`08-17 11:58:47.891 6929 3624 W MastodonAPIController: [goingdark.social_114943819942928907] Response{protocol=h2, code=422, ... url=https://goingdark.social/api/v1/statuses} received error: {"error":"Validation failed: Text can't be blank"}`

From Gboard system log header:  
`type: logcat package: com.google.android.inputmethod.latin:171306542, targetSdk 35 osVersion: google/tokay/tokay:16/BP2A.250805.005/2025081400:user/release-keys`

**Notes:**  
- Switching to a different keyboard (e.g., FUTO Keyboard) resolves the issue; posting works normally.
- Issue is reproducible with Gboard v171306542 on Android 16.

**Impact:**  
Mastodon Android app users on Android 16 with Gboard cannot post or reply to statuses.

comment.body:
> GrapheneOS

That counts as a custom ROM though ‚Äî with modifications that go deep enough to theoretically have the potential to break apps. This never happened to me with Gboard on a Pixel 9 Pro with stock Android 16.

I don't think the `SPAN_EXCLUSIVE_EXCLUSIVE` line in the log has anything to do with this error.

pull_request.title: Fix Streamlit app import error
pull_request.body:
# Fix Streamlit app import error ## Summary Fixed an `ImportError: attempted relative import with no known parent package` that prevented the Streamlit app from loading. The issue occurred because the app was using a relative import (`from .agent import NJVoterChatAgent`) but Streamlit runs the file directly, breaking the package context needed for relative imports. The fix adds the project root directory to `sys.path` before importing, allowing the absolute import to resolve correctly. This enables the Streamlit app to successfully load and initialize the NJVoterChatAgent. ## Review & Testing Checklist for Human - [ ] **Test Streamlit app startup**: Run `streamlit run agents/nj_voter_chat_adk/app_streamlit.py` from project root and verify it loads without import errors - [ ] **Verify agent functionality**: Test that the chat interface works end-to-end (can send queries and get responses from BigQuery) - [ ] **Check path calculation**: Ensure the `os.path.join(os.path.dirname(__file__), '..', '..')` correctly resolves to the project root in your environment - [ ] **Consider deployment scenarios**: Verify this fix will work in your production deployment setup (container, different working directories, etc.) **Recommended test plan**: Start the Streamlit app, verify the interface loads, send a test query like "how many voters are there" and confirm it processes without import errors. --- ### Diagram ```mermaid %%{ init : { "theme" : "default" }}%% graph TD subgraph "Project Structure" A["proj-roth/"] B["agents/nj_voter_chat_adk/"] C["app_streamlit.py"]:::major-edit D["agent.py"]:::context end A --> B B --> C B --> D C -->|"sys.path.insert(0, project_root)
absolute import"| D E["Streamlit Runtime"]:::context --> C subgraph Legend L1["Major Edit"]:::major-edit L2["Minor Edit"]:::minor-edit L3["Context/No Edit"]:::context end classDef major-edit fill:#90EE90 classDef minor-edit fill:#ADD8E6 classDef context fill:#FFFFFF ``` ### Notes - The fix uses `sys.path` manipulation which is generally safe but can be environment-sensitive - Previously the CLI version worked because it used absolute imports, while the Streamlit version used relative imports - This change makes both versions consistent in their import strategy - Tested locally and confirmed the Streamlit app loads successfully with the agent interface **Link to Devin run:** https://app.devin.ai/sessions/70ba3ae6fc8d46b48eb248b1e5354fd1 **Requested by:** Greg (gregtusar@gmail.com)

issue.title: Develop Touptek camera control application
issue.body: Implement a comprehensive Qt C++ application for Touptek ATR2600M camera control and live view. This PR delivers the full application, including camera initialization with specific settings (RAW8, hardware binning, high priority USB), an OpenGL-based live viewer with zoom/pan and animated AE ROI, and a UI panel with SVG icons for all specified camera controls (gain, full well, cooling, heating, still/record capture). ---
